Lewat Pariwisata, Kalimantan Selatan Melepaskan Diri dari Tambang
04 Nov 2019, 13:45 by Afif Farhan


Foto: (dok Kementerian Pariwisata dan Ekonomi Kreatif)

Jakarta - Pariwisata dinilai bisa meningkatkan perekonomian. Itulah yang akan dilakukan Kalimantan Selatan, mengembangkan pariwisata dan melepaskan diri dari tambang.Bertempat di Balairung Soesilo Soedarman, Gedung Sapta Pesona, kantor Kementerian Pariwisata dan Ekonomi Kreatif, Jakarta Pusat, Senin (4/11/2019), Pemprov Kalimantan Selatan menggelar Calender of Event (CoE) dan Visit Kalsel 2020. Kalimantan Selatan punya 32 event pariwisata yang siap digelar di tahun 2020 mendatang.Beberapa eventnya seperti Festival Loksado, Festival Dayak Meratus, Pesta Laut Pulau Manti, Wisata Susur Sungai, Festival Jukung Hias Tanglong, dan lainnya. Lewat berbagai event itu, diharapkan bisa mengundang wisatawan datang dan meningkatkan pendapatan masyarakat."Melalui kegiatan ini, diharapkan akan merangsang investor nasional maupun internasional untuk berinvestasi di Kalimantan Selatan terutama di sektor maritim dan pariwisata," ujar Wakil Gubernur Kalimantan Selatan, Rudy Resnawan.


Foto: (dok Kementerian Pariwisata dan Ekonomi Kreatif)

BACA JUGA: Pesona Alam Bukit Tamiang di KalimantanSelain lewat event, potensi wisata alam dan budaya pun tak boleh diremehkan. Kalimantan Selatan punya Tahura, pasar terapung di Banjarmasin, Pulau kaget, Kawasan Wisata Loksado, hingga Danau Panggan."Lebih banyak wisatawan yang datang, artinya lebih banyak pendapatan yang masuk dan pendapatan daerah bertambah. Makanya, kita mau melepaskan diri dari tambang dan mengembangkan pariwisata," ujar Supiah HK, Ketua Komisi III DPRD Kalsel pada kesempatan yang sama.Menurut Supiah, pertambangan hanya meninggalkan lubang dan merusak ekosistem alam. Namun dengan pariwisata, alam dan budaya bakal terus terjaga."Bulan Desember nanti, Presiden Jokowi juga akan meresmikan Bandara Internasional Syamsudin Noor yang statusnya jadi bandara internasional. Artinya, kita bisa mendatangkan lebih banyak wisatawan dalam negeri dan turis mancanegara," sambungnya.BACA JUGA: Aneka Oleh-oleh Khas dari Kalimantan SelatanSementara itu, Kepala Dinas Pariwisata Provinsi Kalsel, Dahnial Kifli menjelaskan Kalimantan Selatan terus membenahi potensi-potensi pariwisata. Soal budaya, Kalimantan Selatan punya suku Dayak dan suku Banjar."Di gunung ada suku Dayak, di hilir ada suku Banjar. Kalimantan itu terkenal dengan sebutan 'Borneo' termasuk Dayak dan Banjar yang punya beragam budaya. Itu akan kita poles untuk menjadi destinasi wisata dan budaya," ujarnya.Ni Wayan Giri, Deputi Bidang Pengembangan Industri dan Kelembagaan Kementerian Pariwisata dan Ekonomi Kreatif menjelaskan, pihak kementerian akan membantu dan mempromosikan event dan pariwisata Kalimantan Selatan. Pariwisata dinilai memberikan dampak positif untuk pendapatan masyarakat dan kelestarian alam."Perlu diperhatikan aksesibilitas, atraksi, amenitas, promosi, dan pelayanan. Prinsip-prinsip pariwisata berkelanjutan dan kearifan lokal harus terus terjaga," tutupnya.Simak Video "Kaum Ibu di Pasar Terapung, Banjarmasin"[Gambas:Video 20detik](aff/aff)

Through Tourism, South Kalimantan Breaks Away from Mining
Nov 04 2019, 13:45 by Afif Farhan


Photo: (dock of the Ministry of Tourism and Creative Economy)

Jakarta - Tourism is considered to be able to improve the economy. That is what South Kalimantan will do, develop tourism and break away from the mines. Located in the Soesilo Soedarman Hall, Sapta Pesona Building, Ministry of Tourism and Creative Economy Office, Central Jakarta, Monday (4/11/2019), the South Kalimantan Provincial Government held a Calender of Event (CoE) and Visit South Kalimantan 2020. South Kalimantan has 32 tourism events that are ready to be held in 2020. Some events are like the Loksado Festival, Meratus Dayak Festival, Manti Island Sea Party, Susur Sungai Tour, Tanglong Ornamental Jukung Festival, and others. Through these events, it is expected to invite tourists to come and increase people's income. "Through this activity, it is expected to stimulate national and international investors to invest in South Kalimantan, especially in the maritime and tourism sector," said Deputy Governor of South Kalimantan, Rudy Resnawan.


Photo: (dock of the Ministry of Tourism and Creative Economy)

READ ALSO: The Enchanting Nature of Bukit Tamiang in Kalimantan Aside from the event, the potential of natural and cultural tourism should not be underestimated. South Kalimantan has Tahura, a floating market in Banjarmasin, shocked island, Loksado Tourism Area, and Lake Panggan. "More tourists are coming, which means more income is coming in and regional income is increasing. Therefore, we want to break away from mines and develop tourism. , "said Supiah HK, Chair of Commission III of South Kalimantan DPRD on the same occasion. According to Supiah, mining only leaves holes and damages the natural ecosystem. But with tourism, nature and culture will continue to be maintained. "In December, President Jokowi will also inaugurate Syamsudin Noor International Airport whose status is an international airport. That is, we can bring in more domestic and foreign tourists," he continued. READ ALSO : Various Unique Gifts from South Kalimantan Meanwhile, the Head of the South Kalimantan Provincial Tourism Office, Dahnial Kifli explained that South Kalimantan continues to improve tourism potentials. As for culture, South Kalimantan has Dayak and Banjar tribes. "In the mountains there are Dayak tribes, downstream there are Banjar tribes. Kalimantan is known as 'Borneo' including Dayak and Banjar which have a variety of cultures. We will polish it to become a tourist destination and culture, "he said. Ni Wayan Giri, Deputy of Industrial and Institutional Development in the Ministry of Tourism and Creative Economy explained, the ministry would help and promote South Kalimantan tourism and events. Tourism is considered to have a positive impact on people's income and environmental sustainability. "It should be noted that accessibility, attractions, amenities, promotions, and services. The principles of sustainable tourism and local wisdom must be maintained," he concluded. Watch Video "Women in the Floating Market, Banjarmasin "[Gambas: Video 20 seconds] (aff / aff)
